title: AWS S3 bucket writeable for authenticated aws users

summaries.content:
An ACL misconfiguration issue existed on one of our S3 buckets. This misconfiguration allowed any authenticated AWS user to write to this bucket (no read access was permitted). An attacker could theoretically post a file into that bucket that may at some point be accessed by a HackerOne staff member, thinking it's been uploaded by another staff member or some automated system. We improved the ACLs for that S3 bucket to prevent such a concern.

This issue also led us to audit some of our additional S3 buckets, resulting in changes for some of those buckets as well.
summaries.content_html:
An ACL misconfiguration issue existed on one of our S3 buckets. This misconfiguration allowed any authenticated AWS user to write to this bucket (no read access was permitted). An attacker could theoretically post a file into that bucket that may at some point be accessed by a HackerOne staff member, thinking it's been uploaded by another staff member or some automated system. We improved the ACLs for that S3 bucket to prevent such a concern.

This issue also led us to audit some of our additional S3 buckets, resulting in changes for some of those buckets as well.

summaries.content: For those interested, I've recorded a video tutorial on how I accomplished this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_x5VKuFjvrk
summaries.content_html: For those interested, I've recorded a video tutorial on how I accomplished this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_x5VKuFjvrk

activities.message: Sorry, also (assuming you own the bucket), I can remove files, or at least the one I created, test.txt.
activities.markdown_message: Sorry, also (assuming you own the bucket), I can remove files, or at least the one I created, test.txt.

activities.message: Good catch. This is one of our many S3 buckets, but I indeed can view your `test.txt` upload.
activities.markdown_message: Good catch. This is one of our many S3 buckets, but I indeed can view your test.txt upload.

activities.message: We fixed the ACLs on this particular bucket and also found some additional ACL problems on some other buckets, which we corrected as part of this audit. Can you confirm that the issue is resolved?
activities.markdown_message: We fixed the ACLs on this particular bucket and also found some additional ACL problems on some other buckets, which we corrected as part of this audit. Can you confirm that the issue is resolved?

activities.message: Hi @reed, yup, looks good. Can't move or remove files from the bucket (also tried to sync and some others but they didn't work initially anyways). Glad I reported, wasn't 100% sure if I should given I couldn't confirm the ownership.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @reed, yup, looks good. Can't move or remove files from the bucket (also tried to sync and some others but they didn't work initially anyways). Glad I reported, wasn't 100% sure if I should given I couldn't confirm the ownership.

activities.message: Cool, glad to hear. Also, if there's ever a question about ownership of something, you can e-mail us first to confirm.
activities.markdown_message: Cool, glad to hear. Also, if there's ever a question about ownership of something, you can e-mail us first to confirm.

activities.message:
Thanks again for the great report, @yaworsk.

It's always great to see researchers thinking outside the normal web app confines and considering other parts of technical infrastructure that could affect a company. While you weren't able to read any contents from that bucket (and even if you would, everything is encrypted using AES-256), an attacker could theoretically post a file into that bucket that may at some point be accessed by a HackerOne staff member, thinking it's been uploaded by another staff member or some automated system.

This issue also led us to audit some of our additional S3 buckets (we have quite a few), and we found some similar issues among several of them. As such, we are increasing the bounty to take those additional mitigations into account, even though they weren't discovered by you.

Look forward to seeing what you find next! Happy hacking. :-)

additional_data.new_title: AWS S3 bucket writeable for authenticated aws users
additional_data.old_title: AWS ████████████████ writeable for authenticated aws users

activities.message:
Awesome, thanks for the bounty and considering the additional buckets / potential of this!! Was kicking myself for not searching for those once I found the ████████████ bucket and read reed's comments.

And thanks @reed - that's great to know and helpful.
activities.markdown_message:
Awesome, thanks for the bounty and considering the additional buckets / potential of this!! Was kicking myself for not searching for those once I found the ████████████ bucket and read reed's comments.

And thanks @reed - that's great to know and helpful.

vulnerability_information_html:
Hi All,
I know that hackerone-attachments is used for file uploads on reports and so I did a quick scan for similar buckets and found ████████████████. While I can't confirm if you own it or not, it appears that it is publicly writable using the aws cli.

When I tried to write to hackerone-attachments, I get:
"move failed: ./test.txt to s3://hackerone-attachements/test.txt A client error (AccessDenied) occurred when calling the PutObject operation: Access Denied.

However, when I write to ████████████████, I get:
move: ./test.txt to s3://████████████████/test.txt

Hopefully the bucket is yours and this isn't a waste of time. If you do own it, a good thing is the bucket is not publicly readable and the file appears private by default after being written. However, assuming you own it, the security issue would be someone writing something malicious and someone on your team unknowingly opening it.

Pete
